revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Murad Subay | image = Murad Subay.jpg | caption = Murad Subay, 2013 (photo by Sharaf Al-Houthi) | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|7|3}} | birth_place = [[Dhamar, Yemen]] | nationality = Yemeni | known_for = [[Street art]], painting, [[stencil]] | notable_works = {{unbulleted list | ''Color the Walls of Your Streets'' (2012) | ''The Walls Remember Their Faces'' (2012) | ''12 Hours'' (2013) | ''Ruins'' (2015) }} | spouse = Hadil Al-Mowafak | awards = {{unbulleted list | Freedom of Expression Award (2016) | Art for Peace Award (2014) }} | website = https://muradsubay.com/ }}'''Murad Subay''' (born July 3, 1987 in [[Dhamar Governorate|Dhamar]]) is a Yemeni [[contemporary art]]ist, [[street artist]] and a political activist who has launched several [[street art]] campaigns of which society engagement marked one of their important elements. He first started to paint on the streets after [[Yemeni Revolution|the revolution of 2011]], in a campaign he called "Color the Walls of Your Street".<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://revolutionartnow.altervista.org/murad-subay-street-art-yemen/|title=Murad Subay ~ Street Art in Yemen {{!}} •• REVOLUTION ART ••|last=|first=|date=2015-01-21|website=|publisher=|language=en-EN|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://shabab.assafir.com/Article/11494|title=مراد سبيع.. يمنيّ يحلم|last=ترحيني|first=زينب|date=1013-12-24|website=السفير العربي|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.academia.edu/7225425/_The_politics_of_painting_in_public_spaces_Yemeni_street_art_as_a_device_for_political_action_presented_at_the_PARGC_Symposium_The_revolutionary_Public_Sphere_Aesthetics_Poetics_and_Politics_University_of_Pennsylvania_Philadelphia_April_9-10_2014|title=The politics of painting in public spaces: Yemeni street art as a device for political action|last=Alviso-Marino|first=Anahi|publisher=|date=April 2014|isbn=|location=Symposium "The Revolutionary Public Sphere: Aesthetics, Poetics & Politics" University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia|pages=3, 4, 5|via=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.it/2014/11/11/art-for-peace-murad-subay_n_6140566.html|title=La storia dello Yemen in graffiti (FOTO)|last=Barus|first=Donatella|date=2014-11-13|website=L'Huffington Post|publisher=|language=it-IT|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
He became widely known as an [[Activism|activist]] after launching several [[street art]] campaigns that criticized the political situation in his country and the conflicts which broke out in 2015 in [[Yemen]]. Unlike many graffiti artists, Murad does not hide his identity; rather he always paints in the light of day and invites people to join him paint openly in the streets. People from different backgrounds and ages have joined him in his campaigns to express their own views around the political scene in [[Yemen]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibraaz.org/essays/100|title=Making Stories Visible: A Yemeni Art History|last=Alviso-Marino|first=Anahi|date=2014-09-09|website=Ibraaz|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/society/2016/4/18/the-street-artist-exposing-worlds-dirty-legacy-in-yemen|title=The street artist exposing world's 'dirty legacy' in Yemen|last=Searle|first=Fred|date=2016-04-08|website=The New Arab|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/06/qa-painting-tribute-victims-yemen-war-150623115228023.html|title=Q&A: Painting tribute to the victims of Yemen's war|last=Hu|first=Zoe|date=2015-06-25|website=Aljazeera|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.good.is/articles/yemens-banksy-uses-street-art-to-fight-sectarian-violence|title=Yemen's Banksy Uses Street Art to Fight Sectarian Violence|last=Feinstein|first=Laura|date=2015-03-23|website=GOOD Magazine|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ozy.com/rising-stars/murad-subay-the-banksy-of-yemen/32863|title=Murad Subay: The Banksy of Yemen|last=Palet|first=Laura Secorun|date=2014-07-24|website=Ozy|publisher=|language=en-EN|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref> The influence of these campaigns spread to other cities such as [[Sana'a]], [[Taiz]], [[Aden]], [[Ibb]] and [[Al Hudaydah|Alhudaydah]] where similar campaigns were launched soon after.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=http://nationalyemen.com/2015/03/22/graffiti-campaigns-reflect-yemenis-hopes/|title=Graffiti Campaigns Reflect Yemenis' Hopes|last=Al-Arashi|first=Fakhri|date=2015|website=National Yemen|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.psa.ac.uk/sites/default/files/page-files/Alles_EP_No34.pdf|title=Voicing Grievances and Hope through Art: Yemen's Youth Empower Themselves|last=Alles|first=Larissa|publisher=|date=April 2015|isbn=|location=University of St. Andrews|pages=10|via=}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2014/09/youth-yemen-graffiti-art-campaigns-criticize-politics.html#|title=Graffiti Gets Political in Yemen|last=al-Absi|first=Mohammad|date=2014-09-12|website=al-Monitor|publisher=|language=en-us|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Murad Subay was born in [[Dhamar Governorate|Dhamar]], [[Yemen]] on July 3, 1987. He was raised there until the age of 6, before his family moved to live in the capital [[Sana'a]]. He lived in [[Sana'a]] with his mother and six siblings. Murad used to draw at school, but he only became interested in art in the age of 14 when he painted his first sketch and received encouragements from his family. He studied English Literature from 2007 to 2011 at [[Sana'a University]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":8" />
In the spring of 2011, specifically with the start of [[Yemeni Revolution|the peaceful Yemeni revolution]], Murad was one of earliest to join the protestors in their demand of a just, civil state. He used to spend most of his time inside the change square, inspecting the entrants for weapons and joining the peaceful rallies. When the political parties seized control of the course of the revolution, he left the change square disappointed.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/yemen-street-artist_us_57193277e4b0d0042da8a374|title=Yemeni Street Artist Covers The Ruins Of War In Color And Memories|last=Alfred|first=Charlotte|last2=|first2=|date=2016-04-22|website=The World Post|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.academia.edu/7225425/_The_politics_of_painting_in_public_spaces_Yemeni_street_art_as_a_device_for_political_action_presented_at_the_PARGC_Symposium_The_revolutionary_Public_Sphere_Aesthetics_Poetics_and_Politics_University_of_Pennsylvania_Philadelphia_April_9-10_2014|title=The politics of painting in public spaces: Yemeni street art as a device for political action|last=Alviso-Marino|first=Anahi|publisher=|date=April 2014|isbn=|location=Symposium "The Revolutionary Public Sphere: Aesthetics, Poetics & Politics", University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia|pages=3|via=}}</ref>
==The campaigns== === Color The Walls of Your Streets === Subay drew his inspiration to launch his first campaign "Color the Walls of Your Street" from the damaged walls of the streets. He went down alone to the streets with his tools on March 15, 2012 to paint contemporary murals on the walls. He then posted a public invitation for people through his Facebook page to join him in painting openly. A week later, many people showed up to paint with him on March 22, 2012. He then invited people every Thursday morning to join him in painting murals openly, and often painted alone in other days.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/photoblogs/yemen-color-me-wall|title=Yemen: Color Me a Wall|last=Alwazir|first=Atiaf|date=|website=Al-Akhbar English|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.psa.ac.uk/sites/default/files/page-files/Alles_EP_No34.pdf|title=Voicing Grievances and Hope through Art: Yemen's Youth Empower Themselves|last=Alles|first=Larissa|publisher=|date=April 2015|isbn=|location=University of St. Andrews|pages=9|via=}}</ref>
This campaign lasted for three months of which artists, passers-by, elders, children, men, women and even soldiers painted alongside him in different areas in [[Sana'a]] city. The idea of this campaign spread between people and similar campaigns were launched soon after in other cities.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" />
=== The Walls Remember Their Faces === Soon after finishing his first campaign, Subay launched his second campaign which marked the transition to political art. He called the campaign "The Walls Remember Their Faces" on September 8, 2012 to highlight the forcibly disappearance of political activists and journalists from the late 1960s and until 2011. He used [[Stencil graffiti|stencil]] technique to paint the faces of the [[Forced disappearance|forcibly disappeared]] on the walls of the cities and invited their families and people in general to join him.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-disappeared-idUSBRE88O0YG20120925|title=Yemenis paint disappeared activists on Sanaa streets|last=Hammond|first=Andrew|date=2012-09-25|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-08-12|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/31/yemeni-street-artist-disappeared-sanaa-walls?CMP=twt_gu|title=Yemeni street artist uses Sana'a walls to remember the disappeared|last=al-Shamahi|first=Abubakr|date=2013-10-31|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref>
For seven months, Subay asked people on different media to supplement him with information around the [[Forced disappearance|forcibly disappeared]]. Many families responded to him and provided him with pictures, stories and sometimes belongings of the victims. They also joined in painting their disappeared relatives and friends and they held several protests during the campaign.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://universes-in-universe.org/eng/nafas/articles/2013/street_art_yemen|title=From Street Politics to Street Art in Yemen|last=Alviso-Marino|first=Anahi|date=July 2013|website=Nafas Art Magazine|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref> Some of the consequences of this campaign were the creation of a special committee to investigate the cases of enforced disappearance, the discussion over the elaboration of a transitional justice law and the UN pressure on the Yemeni government to sign a convention against enforced disappearance.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" />
Subay and his friends painted the pictures of 102 [[Forced disappearance|forcibly disappeared]] victims in many areas in the cities [[Sana'a]], [[Taiz]], [[Al Hudaydah|Alhudayda]] and [[Ibb]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.victoriacfontan.com/blog/the-cowards-war-the-artist|title=The Coward's War: the artist|last=Fontan|first=Victoria|date=2014-01-20|website=Victoria C. Fontan|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-12}}</ref> Many of these murals were defaced by unidentified people; however, this act did not discourage Subay and his friends from making dozens of duplicates across the city.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" />
=== 12 Hours === On July 4, 2013, Subay launched the third campaign "12 Hours" to discuss 12 political and social issues affecting the Yemeni society and led it off with a mural about spread of weapons. Fellow artists started to join him during the second activity of the campaign which was about [[sectarianism]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.designboom.com/art/12th-hour-yemeni-street-art-campaign-surfaces-political-concerns/|title=12th hour graffiti campaign in yemen surfaces political concern|last=|first=|date=2013-08-27|website=Designboom|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-13}}</ref>
For a whole year, Subay and fellow artists painted murals about a certain subject each month in the streets of [[Sana'a]] city. The 12 topics they discussed were spread of weapons, [[sectarianism]], kidnappings, tempering with homeland, [[US Drone attacks in Yemen|US drones]], [[Poverty in Yemen|poverty]], [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|civil war]], [[Terrorism in Yemen|terrorism]], [[Military use of children|children recruitment]], [[treason]], [[corruption]] and an open topic in the 12th activity of the campaign.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://stream.aljazeera.com/story/201308261924-0023002|title=Painting politics in Yemen|last=|first=|date=2013-08-26|website=Al-Jazeera|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/30/yemen-street-art_n_3838742.html|title=12 Hour Graffiti Campaign Addresses Future Of Yemen|date=2013-08-30|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://world.time.com/2013/11/30/yemens-new-ways-of-protesting-drone-strikes-graffiti-and-poetry|title=Yemen's New Ways of Protesting Drone Strikes: Graffiti and Poetry|last=Root|first=Tik|date=2013-11-30|work=|newspaper=Time|issn=0040-781X|access-date=2016-08-13|via=}}</ref>
Not long enough after "12 Hours" campaign ended, unknown actors vandalized some murals discussing different political issues by covering the original murals with white paint or slogans. The vandalized murals belonged to the tenth hour "treason" that mostly discussed USA, Saudi Arabia and Iran's influence and involvement in the mounting conflicts, and the eleventh hour "corruption" that discussed different forms of corruption in the country.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.academia.edu/22825488/The_Affect_of_the_Drone_Strike_Subays_12_Hours_and_the_Environmental_Resistance_of_Street_Art|title=The Affect of the Drone Strike: Subay's 12 Hours and the Environmental Resistance of Street Art|last=Hoyt|first=Kate|publisher=|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=15|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.psa.ac.uk/sites/default/files/page-files/Alles_EP_No34.pdf|title=Voicing Grievances and Hope through Art: Yemen's Youth Empower Themselves|last=Alles|first=Larissa|publisher=|date=April 2015|isbn=|location=University of St. Andrews|pages=12|via=}}</ref>
=== Dawn Sculptures === In early 2015, specifically on January 15, 2015, Subay launched a forth campaign that he called "Dawn Sculptures". He led it off with an installation about "Elmuqah", an ancient Yemeni symbol that represents the unity of Yemenis and their state 3000 years ago. Subay was meaning to continue working on this campaign, had it not for the power outages and lack of funding that forced him to postpone the activity.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nationalyemen.com/2015/01/18/artist-murad-subaia-launches-new-campaign/|title=Artist Murad Subai'a Launches New Campaign|last=Al-Arashi|first=Fakhri|date=2015|website=National Yemen|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref>
=== Ruins === [[File:Flowers Bouquet Mural.jpg|alt=Flowers Bouquet Mural|thumb|A mural by artist Murad Subay in the first activity of Ruins campaign, painted in Bani Hawat area, Sana'a, on May 18, 2015.]] After the regional and internal conflicts broke out in [[Yemen]] in 2015, Subay launched the fifth campaign "Ruins" on May 18, 2015, to commemorate the victims of the conflicts and to highlight the catastrophic situation of the country. He often paints in the areas ruined due to the conflicts. Subay painted his first mural in the campaign in an area called "[[Bani Hawat]]" located in the suburbs of [[Sana'a]], where an airstrike killed almost 27 civilians, including 15 children.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/afrah-nasser/yemeni-graffiti-artist-ca_b_8742878.html|title=Yemeni Graffiti Artist Capturing War Imprints|last=Nasser|first=Afrah|last2=|date=2015-12-08|website=The Huffington Post|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-15|last3=}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=http://www.alyamanalaraby.com/2051|title=بالصور.. 'حٌطام' توثق الحرب على بقايا الجدران|last=حسن|first=نجلاء|date=2015-11-29|website=اليمن العربي|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref>
His friends began to join him during the second activity of the campaign, in an area called "Faj Attan", a heavily populated area inside the capital [[Sana'a]] where a heavy air strike on a weapons storage facility nearby left behind tens of killed and injured civilians and destroyed the homes of hundreds of people.<ref name=":13" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0NB0R820150420|title=Air strike on missile base in Yemen capital kills 25, wounds hundreds|last=Browning|first=Noah|date=2015-04-20|work=|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-08-15|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spicee.com/fr/program/le-banksy-du-yemen-version-courte-552|title=Le Banksy du Yémen (version courte)|last=Lepetit|first=Sylvain|last2=Fouchet|first2=Julien|date=2015-10-02|website=Spicee|publisher=|language=fr-FR|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref>
In the third activity of the campaign, he painted a mural in [[Taiz]] city, a city that is witnessing a great losses due to the internal and regional [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|conflicts in Yemen]]. He painted the mural in the outer parts of the city because he was banned to go further inside the city by one of the conflict parties.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13" />
For The fourth activity of this campaign, he was planning to paint mural in [[Aden]] city, another city torn by the internal and regional [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|conflicts in Yemen]]. However, because of the dangerous security situation, he could not travel there, so he and his friends painted their murals in Sawan area in [[Sana'a]], yet another area that was targeted by an air strike, leaving tens of killed and injured civilians.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":13" />
The fifth activity discussed another important issue, and that is limiting the journalistic freedoms. Subay and his friends painted the murals inside the Syndicate of Yemeni Journalists, to highlight the systematic detention of journalists and the violations committed against the journalistic freedoms.<ref name=":11" />
After that, in the sixth activity of the campaign, they discussed the issue of the siege on [[Yemen]], whether it was placed by the regional conflict parties or the internal ones, limiting the access of food, medicine, water and humanitarian assistance to those who need it.<ref name=":11" />
Subay painted the seventh mural in [[London]], where he discussed the ignoring of [[international community]] and media of the [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|conflicts in Yemen]].<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":11" />
In the eighth activity of "Ruins" campaign, Subay and fellow artists painted about the economy collapse in [[Yemen]]. They painted the murals in front of [[Central Bank of Yemen|Yemen Central Bank]] after the value of [[Yemeni rial|Yemeni Rial]] against the [[United States dollar|US Dollar]] dropped significantly, adding another misfortune to the already impoverished nation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/07/19/yemen-it%25E2%2580%2599s-economy-stupid|title=Yemen: It's the economy, stupid!|last=Kalfood|first=Mohammed|date=2016-07-19|work=|last2=Slemrod|first2=Annie|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
== Open Painting Days == Aside from painting in the streets through campaigns that each have a special theme, Subay invited people to paint openly in the streets on the third and forth anniversaries of his first [[street art]] campaign "Color the Wall of Your Street" on March 15.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://arabi.assafir.com/Article/4385|title=الفنون المدينية: رسائل على جدران مدن عربية|last=جلّول|first=صباح|date=2016-03-24|website=السفير العربي|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=2016-08-16}}</ref>
=== March 15, 2015 === Through his Facebook page, Subay invited people to paint openly along with him in the streets on the third anniversary of his first [[street art]] campaign "Color the Walls of Your Streets" on March 15, 2015, an event which he called "Humans and Art Day". He invited people to the event to express their love for life, beauty, homeland, and their fear of an expected civil war. They painted on one of the walls of Hadda street in Central [[Sana'a]] city.<ref name=":9" />
=== (March 15 – March 17), 2016 === Due to the many requests Murad received from people next year, he extended the duration of the open painting day event to become three days instead of one, so that many people could have the chance to join in. Murad chose a wall in front of a police station, and from the first day of the event, soldiers and police officers joined them in painting the walls.<ref name=":14" />
==Group exhibitions== 2016 – '''Group Exhibition''', ''Yemeni Film & Arts Festival'', The Yemen Peace Project, NY, USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://meis.as.nyu.edu/object/kc.events.2nd.yemeni.filmfestival|title=The 2nd International Yemeni Film and Arts Festival|last=|first=|date=April 2016|website=New York University|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/festival/nyc/|title=Festival 2016 – New York City|last=|first=|date=April 2016|website=Yemen Peace Project|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2016 – '''Group Exhibition''', ''Yemeni Film & Arts Festival'', The Yemen Peace Project, DC, USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yemenpeaceproject.org/festival/dc/|title=Festival 2016 – Washington DC|last=|first=|date=April 2016|website=Yemen Peace Project|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2014 – '''Group Exhibition''', ''Talk Love .. Act Peace'', Contemporary Art Platform (CAP), Kuwait.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://capkuwait.com/2014/peace-one-day-talk-love-act-peace/|title=Peace One Day: Talk Love…Act Peace|last=|first=|date=2014|website=Contemporary Art Platform|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2014 – '''Group Exhibition''', ''Unrest: Art, Activism & Revolution'', Helen Day Art Center, VT, USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.helenday.com/exhibitions/past/18-unrest|title=Unrest: Art, Activism & Revolution|last=|first=|date=2014|website=Helen Day Art Center|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stowetoday.com/this_week/arts/helen-day-exhibit-showcases-protest-art/article_09205af0-44bb-11e4-9bed-7b328a27c3d8.html|title=Helen Day exhibit showcases protest art|last=Gardner|first=Tommy|date=2014-09-25|website=Stowe Today|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
== Awards/Grants == 2016 - ''Freedom of Expression Arts Award and Fellowship Program'', Index on Censorship Organization, London, UK.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indexoncensorship.org/2016/04/index-announces-winners/|title=Index announces winners of 2016 Freedom of Expression Awards|last=|first=|date=2016-04-13|website=Index on Censorship|publisher=|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2015 - ''Certificate of Appreciation'', UN (ESCWA), Beirut, Lebanon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unescwa.org/events/escwa-celebration-world-day-social-justice|title=ESCWA celebration of the World Day of Social Justice|last=|first=|date=2015-02-20|website=United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2014 - ''The Art for Peace Award'', Veronesi Foundation, Milan, Italy.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://globalvoices.org/2014/05/09/yemens-got-talent/|title=8 Extraordinarily Talented People From Yemen Everyone Should Know|last=Arabia|first=Noon|date=2014-05-09|website=Global Voices|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>
2014 - ''The Youth Shield for Creativity'', Yemeni socialist Party, Sana'a, Yemen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aleshteraky.com/mlhf-fkbiq/item/1624-%D8%BAha%D9%8B-adgeil-afcaadiq-ccjieiq-ddafaf-adcmcidi-ejah-lbir-ai-ebj-adamcjaci-bnfra%D8%A1|title=غداً الخميس احتفالية تكريمية للفنان التشكيلي مراد سبيع في مقر الاشتراكي بصنعاء|last=القباطي|first=بدر|date=2014-06-14|website=الإشتراكي نت|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=}}</ref>
2013 - ''The Innovation Shield'', the American Islamic Congress Organization, Sana'a, Yemen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yemenat.net/?p=101039|title=مهرجان صنعاء لأفلام حقوق الإنسان يختتم فعالياته ويكرم حاشد والأغبري وسبيع وياسر عبد الباقي|last=ردمان|first=حمدي|date=2013-03-06|website=يمنات|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.opiyemen.org/activities/2013/94-2013-07-20-21-50-34.html|title=مهرجان صنعاء لأفلام حقوق الإنسان|last=|first=|date=March 2013|website=المنظمة اليمنية لتعزيز النزاهة OPI|publisher=|language=ar-AR|access-date=2016-08-17}}</ref>

revision.comment: ref name, duplicate references, duplciate categories using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Ngqika people''' are a royal [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] who lived west of the [[Great Kei River]]<ref name="Geni">[https://www.geni.com/people/Ngqika-3rd-Paramount-Chief-of-the-amaRarabe/6000000014480869867 2017. Ngqika ka Mlawu, 3rd Paramount Chief of the amaRarabe. Geni. Accessed 13 March.]</ref> in the what is today the [[Eastern Cape]] of [[South Africa]]. They were first ruled by [[Rharhabe|Rarabe kaPhalo]] who died with his son Mlawu, who was destined for chiefancy. The clan would named after Ngqika ka Mlawu, the son of the then late Mlawu.<ref name="Family tree">[https://www.news24.com/Books/maqomas-final-resistance-20170924-2 2017. Maqoma’s final resistance. News24. Accessed 13 March.]</ref> It would be years before the child would rule his people who fought in the [[Xhosa Wars]] following the invasion of the British and Dutch settlers.<ref name="Invasion">[http://www.sahistory.org.za/article/conquest-eastern-cape-1779-1878 2011. Conquest of the Eastern Cape 1779-1878. SA History. Accessed 13 March.]</ref>
[[File:Eastern Frontier, Cape of Good Hope, ca 1835.png|380px|thumb|Eastern Frontier, Cape of Good Hope, ca 1835]]
The [[Dutch East India Company]] (VOC) that was responsible for trading and colonising of South African land in what is described as “founding” several urban areas like towns and cities in already populated areas of the west of South Africa. The organisation continually changed the boundaries in the [[Cape Colony]] due to European invasion and migration, establishing the Great Fish River as the eastern frontier in 1778.<ref name="Invasion"/>
In colonial times, the Ngqika lands were known as [[British Kaffraria]]. Later the Apartheid government gave them a form of independence as the former "[[Ciskei]]" homeland.
The clan were referred to as “Gaika” people by the Europeans.
==Origins== === Birth of a nation === {{Main|History of South Africa}}
Ngqika ka Mlawu was the first chief of the Ngqika and the third paramount chief of the [[Rharhabe]] people. He had nine wives. The clan was named after him when his grandfather ([[Rarabe kaPhalo|Rharhabe]], the founder of the tribe) and father (Mlawu, who was to be the next chief) both died in 1782. Ngqika, at only four years old, was too young to rule. Ndlambe (who would eventually establish the [[AmaNdlambe]] people) was Rharhabe’s other son and Ngqika’s uncle who became [[regent]] until the boy matured – in the tradition of the Xhosas. Ndlambe was responsible for the expansion of his tribe’s territory and influence.<ref name="Geni"/> He absorbed smaller clans (like the imiDange people) into the Ngqikas or expelled them to far lands. They were eventually invaded by European settlers from the Cape Colony who fought with them over their prime grazing land, west of the [[Great Kei River]].<ref name="Geni" />
The occupation by white settlers ([[Dutch Cape Colony|Dutch]] and [[Cape Colony|British]]) resulted in the century of [[Xhosa Wars]] (commonly known as the Frontier Wars) from 1779 to 1879 involving Xhosa tribes (including the Ngqika), [[Khoikhoi]] and [[San people]]. Relations between the [[Ethnic groups in Europe|European]] invaders were fluid throughout this period with the varying indigenous people and Europeans working for or against one another to secure land, resources and cattle. These groups changed allies depending on who would help advance their objectives over the years. In 1793, in collaboration with other Xhosa clans, the Ngqikas fought against white settlers during the Second Frontier War.<ref name="Geni" />
In 1796, Ngqika turned 18 and was ready to assume his rightful place on the throne, but his uncle was reluctant to give up power. Ndlambe appealed to the tribe to retain his power but this failed. His nephew imprisoned him a year later in an attempt to stifle his power. When he escaped across the Great Fish River in 1799 with his supporters, he attempted to collude with the Cape Colony’s white government to overthrow Ngqika, but the colony continued to recognise his nephew as the paramount chief.<ref name="Geni" />
Ngqika ka Mlawu died in November 1829 after a chest illness and alcohol abuse.<ref name="Family tree"/>
[[File:Mgolombane Sandile - Xhosa Chief.jpg|thumb|left|Mgolombane Sandile - Xhosa Chief]]
=== List of chiefs during Xhosa Wars === {{Main|Xhosa Wars}}
Mgolombane Sandile the rightful heir of Ngqika, was only nine years old when his father died. Mnqoma, born to Ngqika and Nomvakalisa Nothontho of the Ngqosini, was the chief’s eldest son but because Sandile’s mother was a descendent of abaThembu (a royal lineage).<ref name="Family tree" /> Her first son was thus considered the “Great Son”. Mnqoma became regent until Sandile was ready to rule. The following is a list of chiefs of the Ngqika that ruled during the [[Xhosa Wars]] starting with Sandile’s great grandfather, Rharhabe:
*Rharhabe: lived 1778 (as the leader of the [[Rharhabe]] people) – 1782, ruled 1796 - 1782 *Ngqika: lived 1778 – 1829, ruled 1796 - 1829 *Mgolombane Sandile: lived 1820 – 1878, ruled 1841 - 1878<ref name="Family tree" />
The native groups lost most of their land and were absorbed into the British empire during this century. The Xhosa eventually lost access to the fertile land between the [[Great Kei River]] and [[Great Fish River]] to British colonists.<ref name="Amalinde">[http://www.bctourism.co.za/itemdetail.php?id=566&category=15 2017. Battle of Amalinde. Buffalo City. Accessed 13 March.]</ref>
== See also == *[[Albany, South Africa]] *[[History of Cape Colony from 1806 to 1870]] *[[British Kaffraria]] *[[Kaffraria]] *[[Military history of South Africa]] *[[Mgolombane Sandile]] *[[The Battle of Amalinde]] *[[Great Kei River]] *[[Great Fish River]]

==External links== {{commons category|Ngqika people}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070630090942/http://www.justdone.co.za/ROH/List_Wars.asp List of wars]
[[Category:Xhosa-speaking peoples]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in South Africa]] [[Category:History of South Africa]]

{{Infobox film | name = One Away | image = "One_Away"_(1976).jpg | caption = [[VHS]] cover | director = [[Sidney Hayers]] | producer = | writer = | music = [[Ron Grainer]] | narrator = | starring = Patrick Mower
Bradford Dillman
Roberta Durrant
Elke Sommer | cinematography = Graham Edgar | editing = John D. Guthridge | studio = Silhouette Film Productions | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1976}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''One Away''''' is a 1976 American [[action film]] directed by [[Sidney Hayers]] and starring [[Patrick Mower]], [[Bradford Dillman]], [[Roberta Durrant]] and [[Elke Sommer]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075013/|title=One Away|date=1 January 2000|publisher=|via=IMDb}} Two brothers help their brother escape from a [[South African]] jail, sparking a [[Manhunt (law enforcement)|manhunt]].{{cite web|url=http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/302115|title=One Away (1976)|publisher=}} ==Cast== * [[Patrick Mower]] as Tam Bass * [[Bradford Dillman]] as Ruben Bass * [[Elke Sommer]] as Elsa * [[Dean Stockwell]] as Pete Bass * Roberta Durrant as Olwen * [[Ian Yule]] as Stiffy * Erica Rogers as Dot Bass * [[Gordon Mulholland]] as Detective, 'Big man' * [[Patrick Mynhardt]] as Chief warder * Stuart Parker as Warder * Colin Abraham as Convict * Errol Ross as First Warder (Quarry) ==References== {{Sidney Hayers}} [[Category:1976 films]] [[Category:1970s action thriller films]] [[Category:American action thriller films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Sidney Hayers]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]] [[Category:Films set in South Africa]] {{action-thriller-film-stub}}

{{Ethnic group | group = Putianese
莆仙人/興(兴)化人
Pó-sing-náng/Hing-hua̍-náng
Putian Han 莆田漢人 | population = Above 5,000,000 | caption = | region1 = {{CHN}}, [[Southeast Asia]] | languages = [[Puxian Min]], [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], and [[Min Nan]] | religions = Predominantly [[Mahayana Buddhism]], [[Confucianism]], [[Taoism]], [[Traditional Chinese religion]] or [[Atheism]] | related =[[Minyue|Ancient Minyue people]]†, [[Fuzhou people]], [[Hoklo people]], Leizhou Min speakers and other [[Han Chinese]] }} The '''Putian people''', ([[Chinese language|Chinese]]: 莆田人, [[pinyin]]: ''Pútiánrén''; [[Puxian Min]]: 莆仙儂, [[Hinghwa Romanized]]: {{lang|cpx|Pó-sing-náng}}) also known as '''Henghua''' or '''Hinghwa''' are [[Han Chinese]] people from [[Putian]], part of [[Fujian|Fujian Province]], [[China]]. They speak [[Puxian Min]], a [[Min Nan|Min language]]. Min is one of the [[Sinitic languages]]. They may also be referred to as ''Xinghua''. Hing Hua district was carved out from [[Quanzhou]] district during the Song dynasty and was given the name HingHua. Putianese people originated from [[Xinyang]] in what is now [[Henan province]] and migrated to the present day area of Putian many centuries ago. Putianese people were said to be mostly in charge of religious affair during that era, and migrated to Fujian after the [[civil war]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} They are referred to as ''Henghua'' in [[Malaysia]].{{cite book |title=Chinese Overseas: Comparative Cultural Issues |authorlink= Chee Beng Tan |year= |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |page=92 }} Today, there are significantly large Henghua [[diaspora]] communities throughout [[Southeast Asia]], especially in [[Malaysia]] where they can be found in cities such as [[Kuala Terengganu]] and [[Kuching]]. In [[Indonesia]], most Henghua live in [[Java]] and since long have been known for their businesses that mainly related with [[bicycle]] and [[transportation]] vehicles. ==Notable people== ===Historical=== * [[Mazu (goddess)|Mazu]]: Chinese goddess * [[Cai Xiang]]: Chinese [[calligrapher]], [[poet]], scholar and official * [[Chen Wenlong]]: a Zhuangyuan (状元) after topping first place in the [[Imperial Examinations]] and one of the three military heroes of [[Southern Song Dynasty]]. ===Modern=== * [[John Sung]]: Christian [[evangelism|evangelist]] * [[Ng Teng Fong]]: richest person in Singapore * [[Dato Sri Tahir]] or Ang Tjoen Ming: Founder and CEO, [[Mayapada Group]], Indonesia * [[Mochtar Riady]]: Founder, [[Lippo Group]], Indonesia * [[Sukanto Tanoto]]: Founder, Raja Garuda Mas International (now [[Royal Golden Eagle]]), Indonesia * [[James Riady]]: Son of [[Mochtar Riady]]; Deputy chairman, [[Lippo Group]], Indonesia *[[Moses Lim]], Singapore comedian and actor. *[[Ng Eng Hen]], [[Minister of Defence (Singapore)]]. * [[Che Yin Wong]] ({{lang|zh-hans|黄志贤}}, 1959−): Businessman and philanthropist, [[Hong Kong]];[http://www.ptxw.com/jjpd/psfc/20071108/X99004362.shtml] Founder and chairman of Kong Fung International Group * [[Theresa Fu]] (1984-) Hong Kong singer and actress. == See also == * [[Pu-Xian Min]] * [[Fuzhou people]] * [[Hoklo people]] * [[Putian]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Fujian topics}} {{Han subgroups}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in China]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malaysia]] [[Category:Fujian]] [[Category:Putian]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ made parts of link title lowercase
revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Qimant |nativename=Kemantney |states=[[Ethiopia]] |region=[[Amhara Region]] |ethnicity=172,000 (1994 census)<ref name=e18/> |speakers={{sigfig|1650|2}} |date=1994 census |ref=e18 |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Cushitic languages|Cushitic]] |fam3=[[Agaw languages|Agaw]] |fam4=Northern |dia1=[[Qwara language|Qwara]] |dia2=[[Kayla language|Kayla]] |iso3=ahg |glotto=qima1242 |glottorefname=Qimant |notice=IPA }}
The '''Qimant''' language is a highly [[endangered language]] spoken by a small and elderly fraction of the [[Qemant]] people in northern [[Ethiopia]], mainly in the [[Chilga]] [[Districts of Ethiopia|woreda]] in [[Semien Gondar Zone]] between [[Gondar]] and [[Metemma]].
==Classification== The language belongs to the western branch of the Agaw or [[Central Cushitic languages]].<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 30</ref> Other (extinct) members of this branch are [[Qwara language|Qwara]] and [[Kayla language|Kayla]]. Along with all other [[Cushitic languages]], Qimant belongs to the [[Afro-Asiatic]] [[language family]].
==Geographic distribution and sociolinguistic situation== Qimant is the original language of the [[Qemant]] people of [[Semien Gondar Zone]] and [[Ethiopia]]. Although the ethnic population of the Qemant was 172,327 at the 1994 census, only a very small fraction of these speak the language nowadays. All speakers live either in [[Chilga]] woreda or in [[Lay Armachiho]] woreda.<ref>see map in Zelealem 2003, p. 31</ref> The number of first-language speakers is 1625, the number of second language speakers 3450.<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 62</ref> All speakers of the language are older than 30 years, and more than 75% are older than 50 years.<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 63</ref> The language is no longer passed on to the next generation of speakers. Most ethnic Qemant people speak [[Amharic language|Amharic]]. Qimant is not spoken in public or even at house as a means of day communication any more, but is reduced to a secret code.<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 75</ref>
===Dialects/Varieties===
It is not clear to what extent [[Kayla language|Kayla]], [[Qwara language|Qwara]] and Qimant have been dialects of the same Western Agaw language, or were languages distinct from each other.
==Phonology==
===Consonants===
{| class="IPA wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+'''[[Consonant]] phonemes'''<ref name="Zelealem 2003, p. 158">Zelealem 2003, p. 158</ref> ! rowspan="2" colspan="2"| ! rowspan="2"|[[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! rowspan="2"|[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2"|[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2"|[[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- ! <small>plain</small> ! <small>[[labialization|lab.]] |- ! colspan="2"| [[Nasal stop|Nasal]] | m | n |   | ŋ | ŋʷ |- ! rowspan="2"|[[Stop consonant|Stop]] !<small>voiceless</small> |   | t | tʃ | k | kʷ |- !<small>[[voice (phonetics)|voiced]]</small> | b | d | dʒ | ɡ | ɡʷ |- ! rowspan="2"| [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !<small>voiceless</small> | f | s | ʃ | χ | χʷ |- !<small>voiced</small> |   | z |   | ɣ | ɣʷ |- ! colspan="2"|[[Tap consonant|Tap]] |   | r |   |   |   |- ! colspan="2"|[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | l | j |   | w |}
[[Continuant]]s can be geminated word-medially.
===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+'''[[Vowel]] phonemes'''<ref name="Zelealem 2003, p. 158"/> !   ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Central vowel|Central]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA|i}} | {{IPA|ɨ}} | {{IPA|u}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] |   | {{IPA|ə}} | {{IPA|o}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] |   | {{IPA|a}} |   |}
===Phonotactics=== The maximum [[Syllable#Structure|syllable structure]] in Qimant is CVC, which implies that [[consonant cluster]]s are only allowed word-medially.<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 160f</ref> In loanwords from Amharic there may also be consonant-clusters within a syllable. Vowel clusters are not allowed.
===Phonological processes=== [[Consonant cluster]]s with more than two consonants are broken up by inserting the [[epenthetic vowel]] {{IPA|/ɨ/}}. Other phonological processes are [[nasal assimilation]] and [[devoicing]] of {{IPA|/ɡ/}} at word boundaries.<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 164ff</ref>
===Prosody=== The prosodic features of Qimant have not been studied yet.
==Grammar==
===Morphology=== The personal marking system distinguishes between first person singular and plural, second person singular, polite, and plural, and third person masculine, feminine and plural. On the verb, all inflectional categories are marked by suffixes. Zelealem (2003, p. 192) identifies three different aspect forms in Qimant: Perfective, Imperfective and Progressive. Like in other [[Central Cushitic languages]], the numbers one to nine go back to an ancient [[quinary]] system, where the suffix {{IPA|/-ta/}} added to the numbers two to four results in the numbers six to nine {{clarify|date=July 2013}} (2-4 are three numbers, 6-9 are four numbers).<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 233</ref>
===Syntax<ref>Zelealem 2003, p. 252-262</ref>=== The basic constituent order in Qimant, like in all other Afro-Asiatic languages of Ethiopia, is SOV. The presence of a [[grammatical case|case]] marking system allows for other, more marked orders. In the [[noun phrase]] the [[phrase|head]] [[noun]] follows its modifiers. Numbers, however, can also follow the head noun. All kind of [[subordinate clause]]s precede the [[main verb]] of the sentence.
==Vocabulary/Lexis== As a consequence of the looming language death, many items of the vocabulary are already replaced by [[Amharic]] words.
==References==
* Zelealem Leyew. 2003. ''The Kemantney Language – A Sociolinguistic and Grammatical Study of Language Replacement''. Cologne: Rüdiger Köppe Verlag. * David L. Appleyard. 1975. "A descriptive outline of Kemant," ''Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies'' 38:316-350.
== Notes == <references/>
==External links== * [http://www-01.sil.org/silesr/2002/031/SILESR2002-031.pdf Qimant phonology and grammar] * [[World Atlas of Language Structures]] information on [http://wals.info/languoid/lect/wals_code_kem Kemant]
{{Languages of Ethiopia}} {{Cushitic languages}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox military person |name= Robert Russell Garwood |image= |caption= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1946|4|1}} |nickname= Bobby |birth_place= [[Greensburg, Indiana]] |death_place= |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= |allegiance= [[United States of America]] |branch=[[File:USMC logo.svg|20px]] [[United States Marine Corps]] |serviceyears= 1964–1975 |rank=[[United States Marine Corps rank insignia#Enlisted|Private First Class]] |unit= |battles= [[Vietnam War]] |awards= |laterwork= }}
'''Robert Russell Garwood''' (born April 1, 1946) is a controversial former [[Vietnam War]] [[prisoner of war]] (POW). Garwood was a [[United States Marine Corps]] [[Private First Class]]<ref name="FOIA">{{cite web|author=Defense Intelligence Agency |url=http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/Personnel_and_Personnel_Readiness/POW_MIA/659.pdf|title=The Case of Pvt. Robert R. Garwood, USMC |publisher=U.S. Department of Defense |date= June 1993 |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> when he was captured on September 28, 1965 near [[Da Nang]], [[Quang Nam Province]].
Often cited as the last verified American POW from the Vietnam War, Garwood was taken to [[North Vietnam]] in 1969, and reportedly was released in 1973 along with the other American POWs. The North Vietnam government may have kept him as a POW until June 4, 1975 for propaganda reasons until the war ended. After June 4, 1975 he would have no propaganda value as the United States ceased fighting in the Vietnam combat area. However, he did not return to the United States until March 22, 1979.<ref name="FOIA"/>
Garwood was judged by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] (DoD) to have acted as a [[collaboration|collaborator]] with the enemy.<ref name="FOIA" /> In 1998, the DoD changed Garwood's status from RETURNEE to [[AWOL]]/[[Deserter]]/[[Collaborationism|Collaborator]].<ref name="Bio, Garwood, Robert R">{{cite web | url=http://www.pownetwork.org/bios/g/g047.htm | title=Bio, Garwood, Robert R |publisher=pownetwork.org}}</ref>
Garwood has repeatedly denied all charges of collaboration. He also accuses the DoD of trying to rewrite history to make him seem a liar to downplay his 1984 claims about POWs left behind. Garwood's claims were investigated but found to have no factual basis.
==Military service and capture== Garwood was assigned to the Marine Corps base at Da Nang in the [[Republic of Vietnam]] as a [[Fleet vehicle|motor pool]] driver. The circumstances surrounding his disappearance are in dispute. Garwood claims he was ambushed when he got lost when driving alone in a jeep to pick up an officer. He says his jeep was torched and he was stripped naked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3rdmarines.net/Garwood_intro.htm |title=The Case of Robert Garwood PFC 1965 |publisher=3rdmarines.net |date= |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref> Marine Corps records show on 28 September 1965, Garwood was absent at the 2300 bed check. No unauthorized absence (UA) was reported, since he was thought to have had a "late run." He was reported UA when he failed to appear at formation the next morning.<ref name="FOIA" />
On 29 September, the Division [[Provost Marshal]] was notified of Garwood's absence and an all points bulletin issued for him and his vehicle. This was repeated for three days with no results. Motor pool personnel searched the areas of Da Nang that Garwood was known to frequent, but nothing was found. On 2 October, the division's Provost Marshal notified the Republic of Vietnam's Military Security Services. Their search efforts also produced no information. Garwood's commanding officer reported to the Commandant, USMC, that in view of Garwood's past record of UA, he believed he had gone UA again and had possibly been taken POW. However, he recommended there be no change in Garwood's status and that he remain UA until evidence proved otherwise.
Two separate South Vietnamese agents eventually reported that the [[Viet Cong]] claimed a U.S. serviceman and his jeep had been picked up in the Cam Hai region, about 11.5 miles from the Da Nang Marine Corps base, when the serviceman had become lost. The American had been captured and the jeep burned. However, a ground and aerial search for the burned vehicle produced no results, nor did four platoon search operations on 1 October. Two additional infantry platoons swept the area near [[Marble Mountains (Vietnam)|Marble Mountain]] the next morning but also found nothing. On 12 October, the 704th ITC Det (CI) authorized a 100,000 [[South Vietnamese đồng|VND]] reward for information leading to the recovery of the missing serviceman and additional 2,500 VND for the recovery of the vehicle.
On 3 December 1965, Company I, [[3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines#Search and Destroy Near Da Nang (1965–1966)|3rd Battalion, 3rd Marines]] found a document titled ''Fellow Soldier's Appeal'' with Garwood's name on it, on a gate near Da Nang. The document recommended that U.S. troops stop fighting in Vietnam and return home. The signature (B. Garwood) may well have been made by a rubber stamp and the English usage suggests it was not written by a native English speaker. A second version of this document was found on 18 July 1966 in the Da Nang area, but it appeared to be on better quality paper and the signature was at a different angle. Based on these, on 17 December 1965 Garwood's status was changed from "missing" to "presumed captured".<ref name="FOIA" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3rdmarines.net/Garwood_intro.htm |title=The Strange Case of PFC Robert Garwood |publisher=3rdmarines.net |date= |accessdate=2010-09-12}}</ref>
On 15 July 1968, a Marine Corps reconnaissance team named ''Dublin City'' operating in the vicinity of Troui Mountain near [[Phu Bai Combat Base|Phu Bai]] engaged a Viet Cong unit. According to contemporaneous debriefing notes, now declassified, four members of Dublin City reported that the one of the VC fighters was a Caucasian, who was shot during the action and yelled to his VC comrades "Help me!!" in English.<ref>{{cite web|author=Commanding Officer J.V. Sullivan, First Force Recon|url=http://media.nara.gov/usmc/014/00000829.pdf |title=Command Chronology, July1968|publisher=First Marine Division, FMF |date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}}</ref> The "white VC" was described as 20–25 years old, with brown hair, 5' 6" tall, "round eyes", and speaking very distinct English. Because they were outnumbered, ''Dublin City'' broke off contact with the enemy but were followed. In a subsequent firefight a few minutes later, PFC C.G. Brown was killed. In September, 2011, 43 years later, President Obama awarded one team-member of ''Dublin City'', James Wilkins, a [[Silver Star]] for heroism on that day.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jody Wynnemer|url=http://www.newrichlandstar.com/jnews/index.php?page=&view=article&id=626:courage-under-fire|title=Courage Under Fire|publisher=The Star Eagle|date= |accessdate=2014-06-12}}</ref> Following receipt of the Silver Star, he recalled the white VC incident and stated "Myself and three other Marines looked at about 200 photos of guys who were missing in action. All of us were positive it was Bob Garwood, who apparently had defected and was helping the VC."
==1973-1979== Garwood is listed either as having volunteered or been forced into a work group repairing a generator at Lien Trai I, one of the [[Yên Bái Province|Yen Bai]] reeducation camps near Hoang Lien San Mountain in northern Vietnam.<ref>{{cite web|author=Defense Intelligence Agency |url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/pwmia/53/20771.pdf |title=Sighting of Robert Garwood |publisher=Library of Congress |date= |accessdate=2010-09-12}}</ref> Other reports describe him as working at an unnamed "island fortress" in [[Thác Bà Lake]], North Vietnam,<ref name="FOIA"/> or having been kept behind in mainland labor camps<ref>{{cite web|author=Joseph Schlatter |url=http://www.miafacts.org/islefort.htm |title=Smith & Garwood, 1993 |publisher=Miafacts.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> as a driver and vehicle mechanic.<ref name="aiipowmia.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiipowmia.com/inter/inantonres3998.html |title=InterNetwork |publisher=Aii Pow-Mia |date=1998-03-08 |accessdate=2010-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509174926/http://www.aiipowmia.com/inter/inantonres3998.html |archivedate=May 9, 2006 }}</ref>
==Court-martial== Over a period of eleven months, Garwood faced a general [[court-martial]] at [[Camp Lejeune]], North Carolina. He was found not guilty of desertion, solicitation of U.S. troops in the field to refuse to fight and to defect, and of maltreatment. However, he was convicted on February 5, 1981, of communicating with the enemy, and of the assault on an American prisoner of war interned in a POW camp, in violation of Articles 104 and 128, [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]]. The court-martial sentenced Garwood to reduction to private, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, and a dishonorable discharge. He was not sentenced to confinement. His conviction was upheld on appeal. ''United States v. Robert R. Garwood'', 16 M.J. 863 (N.C.M.R. 1983), aff'd, 20 M.J. 148 (C.M.A. 1985). Garwood's record of trial covered 16 volumes and 3,833 pages of trial record. As a result, Garwood forfeited all back pay and veterans' benefits.
==Post-war POW claim investigation== Garwood insists he saw other American prisoners of war after 1973 and insists he himself had been held prisoner for 14 years,<ref name="Bio, Garwood, Robert R"/> though there are inconsistencies in his story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miafacts.org/thachba.htm |title=Thach Ba |publisher=Miafacts.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref> Many former POWs claim to have seen Garwood apparently collaborating with the enemy,<ref name="aiipowmia.com"/> though some feel he should not have been court-martialed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,920202,00.html |title=Nation: The Last P.O.W. |publisher=TIME |date=1979-04-09 |accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref>
In June 1992, a U.S. task force examined the sites where Garwood claimed to have seen live U.S. prisoners. They interviewed nearby residents and met with Vietnamese officials. However, the task force reported that "no evidence could be found to suggest that there are, or ever were, any live U.S. POWs" in those areas.<ref name="FOIA" />
The [[Defense Intelligence Agency]] (DIA), which called Garwood a "[[stay-behind]],"<ref name="FOIA"/> investigated Garwood's claim that he saw live American POWs after 1973 at a "motel-shaped masonry building" in North Vietnam. The DIA reported it could not locate any masonry structures at the indicated location. Senator [[Robert C. Smith|Bob Smith]] requested that the DIA search again. After a second search produced no results, Smith initiated a personal search with [[ABC News]], Garwood, and Bill Hendon. The group traveled to Vietnam in 1993. Following Garwood's directions, they reported they did find a building exactly as Garwood had described it. The Vietnamese government and a former head of the DIA POW/MIA office<ref>{{cite web|author=Joseph Schlatter |url=http://www.miafacts.org/islefort.htm |title=Smith & Garwood, 1993 |publisher=Miafacts.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref> angrily disputed the finding, insisting the structure had not existed when Garwood was a POW.
==Media== ===Film=== The made-for-TV film ''The Last P.O.W.? The Bobby Garwood Story,'' starring [[Ralph Macchio]] and [[Martin Sheen]], was released in 1992. Garwood, played by Macchio, was a consultant on the film. The film's [[Film producer|producers]] claimed that Garwood had received orders to survive from another higher ranking POW. However, there is no substantiation for this claim.
Garwood was also interviewed in 2006 by [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3890677/?ref_=nv_sr_1 Sean Clifford] for a [[Yale University]] [[senior thesis]] project. The project involved a [[documentary film]] component and Garwood participated in more than eight hours of videotaped interviews. The film included interviews with Garwood's [[court-martial]] attorney, Vaughan Taylor, and fellow former POW David Harker. The interviews with Garwood were the first in more than a decade and they represented his most complete account to date of the events surrounding his capture and eventual return to the United States.
===Books=== *''BOHICA : Operation Grand Eagle-Official USA/ISA POW/MIA Rescue Mission Gone Awry,'' published 1987 written by Scott T. Barnes, Mission Specialist. Debriefing of Robert Garwood in 1986 with LTG Tighe Jr-DIA. Also featured in "Kiss the Boys Goodbye" and over 23 other books, testified under oath before US Senate and US Congressional committees investigating the fate of US POW/MIAs, only person to undergo numerous truth serum tests, polygraphs all under oath, Scott Barnes passed all tests and then testified in secret into the "Vault" that testimony is still classified to this date. *''Conversations With The Enemy: The Story of PFC Robert Garwood,'' published 1983, written by [[Winston Groom]] with [[Duncan Spencer]]. Groom, himself also a Vietnam veteran, also wrote the novel ''[[Forrest Gump (novel)|Forrest Gump]]'' and its follow-up novel, ''Gump & Co.'' *''Kiss the Boys Goodbye,'' published 1990, written by Monika Jensen-Stevenson, a producer for CBS's ''60 Minutes'' in 1985. The book begins with a segment she produced on Garwood. *''Spite House,'' published 1997 and also written by Monika Jensen-Stevenson, gives a detailed account of an attempt by one of Lt. Colonel McKenny's commando teams to kill Garwood in a North Vietnamese jungle camp for allegedly collaborating with the enemy. It then tells of McKenney's conversion from a would-be assassin into someone who now believes in Garwood's innocence. *''Why Didn't You Get Me Out?'' published 1997, written by [[Frank Anton]] with Tommy Denton, gives a detailed account of Frank's five years as a POW. He offers extensive eye-witness accounts of Garwood and his collaboration with the NVA, claiming he even saw Garwood using a rifle to guard American POWs.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Garwood, Robert R.}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:American prisoners of war]] [[Category:People from Greensburg, Indiana]] [[Category:United States Marines]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps personnel who were court-martialed]] [[Category:Vietnam War POW/MIA issues]]

The use of a '''royal motto''' ({{lang-da|valgsprog}}) is an old tradition among [[Denmark|Danish]] monarchs, dating back at least 500 years. The use of such a motto was a way for a monarch to emphasize values or beliefs he / she held dear. In earlier times, these mottos were often shown on Danish coinage, often in a [[Latin]] form.
'''Royal mottos'''
{| class="wikitable" | align="center" ! Regent || Reign || Royal motto (in [[Danish language|Danish]]) || Latin or other version || [[English language|English]] translation |- | [[Christian II of Denmark|Christian II]] || 1513 – 1523 || Så var det beskikket || - || Thus it was ordained |- | [[Frederick I of Denmark|Frederick I]] || 1523 – 1533 || Mit håb er Gud alene || - || My hope is God alone |- | [[Christian III of Denmark|Christian III]] || 1536 – 1559 || Ske Herrens vilje || SPES MEA SOLUS DEUS
Zu Gott mein Trost
allein {{De icon}} || The Lord's will be done |- | [[Frederick II of Denmark|Frederick II]] || 1559 – 1588 || Intet uden Gud || DEUS REFUGIU ET FIDUSIA MEA
Mein Hofnung zu
Godt allein {{De icon}} || Nothing without God |- | [[Christian IV of Denmark|Christian IV]] || 1588 – 1648 || Fromhed styrker rigerne || REGNA FIRMAT PIETAS || Piety strengthens the realms[http://www.frederiksborg-slotskirke.dk/index.php?id=8036 Frederiksborg Palace Church - History] {{da icon}} |- | [[Frederick III of Denmark|Frederick III]] || 1648 – 1670 || Herren være mit forsyn || DOMINUS PROVIDEBIT || The Lord will be my guide |- | [[Christian V of Denmark|Christian V]] || 1670 – 1699 || Med fromhed og retfærdighed || PIETATE ET IUSTITIA || With piety and justice |- | [[Frederick IV of Denmark|Frederick IV]] || 1699 – 1730 || Herren være min hjælper || DOMINUS MIHI ADIUTOR || The Lord be my aid |- | [[Christian VI of Denmark|Christian VI]] || 1730 – 1746 || For Gud og folket || DEO ET POPULO || For God and the people |- | [[Frederick V of Denmark|Frederick V]] || 1746 – 1766 || Med klogskab og standhaftighed || PRUDENTIA ET CONSTANTIA || By prudence and steadfastness |- | [[Christian VII of Denmark|Christian VII]] || 1766 – 1808 || Fædrelandets kærlighed er min berømmelse || GLORIA EX AMORE PATRIÆ || The love of the fatherland
is my reward |}
Since the time of Frederick VI, Danish monarchs have only used mottos in the Danish language.
{| class="wikitable" | align="center" ! Regent || Reign || Royal motto (in [[Danish language|Danish]]) || [[English language|English]] translation |- | [[Frederick VI of Denmark|Frederick VI]] || 1808 – 1839 || Gud og den retfærdige sag || God and the just cause |- | [[Christian VIII of Denmark|Christian VIII]] || 1839 – 1848 || Gud og fædrelandet || God and the fatherland |- | [[Frederick VII of Denmark|Frederick VII]] || 1848 – 1863 || Folkets kærlighed, min styrke || The people's love, my strength |- | [[Christian IX of Denmark|Christian IX]] || 1863 – 1906 || Med Gud for ære og ret || With God for honour and justice |- | [[Frederick VIII of Denmark|Frederick VIII]] || 1906 – 1912 || Herren er min hjælper || The Lord is my aid |- | [[Christian X of Denmark|Christian X]] || 1912 – 1947 || Min Gud, mit land, min ære || My God, my country, my honour |- | [[Frederick IX of Denmark|Frederick IX]] || 1947 – 1972 || Med Gud for Danmark || With God for Denmark |- | [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Margrethe II]] || 1972 – || Guds hjælp, folkets
kærlighed, Danmarks styrke || God's help, the people's love,
Denmark's strength |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[List of Danish monarchs]] * [[Royal mottos of Swedish monarchs]] * [[Royal mottos of Norwegian monarchs]] [[Category:Danish monarchy]] [[Category:Lists of mottos|Denmark]]

{{for|the language|Sanumá language}} {{infobox ethnic group |group=Sanumá |total=approx. 1500 |popplace=[[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]] |langs=[[Sanumá language]] |related=[[Yanomami]] }} The '''Sanumá''', also referred to as ''Sanema, Sanima Tsanuma, Guaika, Samatari, Samatali, Xamatari'' and ''Chirichano'' in the literature, are an [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous people]] of [[Brazil]] and [[Venezuela]]. They are related to the [[Yanomami]]. They number about 1500 and live on both sides of the border. In Venezuela they are found in the [[Caura River (Venezuela)|Caura River]] and [[Ventuari River]] basins where they live alongside the [[Ye'kuana]]. The [[Sanumá language]] is a [[Yanomam]] language.
==Gold diggers == On 24 October 2006, their reserve in Venezuela was invaded by miners who destroyed some of their villages. In retaliation the Venezuelan army killed 10 miners. This incident led to mass protests by non-Indians in Southern Venezuela.
==Further reading== *Bruce Parry,''Tribe: Adventures in a Changing World'' (Michael Joseph Raped Ltd, 2007) *Alcida Ramos, ''Sanuma Memories: Yanomami Ethnography in Times of Crisis '' (University of Wisconsin Press, 1995)
